*[Update on Refund workflow automation]*

From the past week, we have been testing the script with various tickets, identifying issues and fixing those along with refactoring  of the code. Now, once the current code is deployed to prod, expectation is to use the script - run it via the dashboard and use the response draft to solve the tickets.

Additionally, there are some legs to the whole flow that need to be taken care of like Genius generating the user intent to create email templates, handling cases with multiple order ids, prod deployment of the "fetch merchant id" api and script to consume the response etc. in addition to deployment of the refactored code.

Have jotted down the various actionable in the <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1J2ZU8kT-95-iokehHMoA0Z-UQJLrgfV5u49XIBJyeSs/edit#gid=254245368|sheet>. Can you guys please provide an approx ETA so that we have an estimate of end to end refund ticket automation? @satoru @Arnab Banerjee @Anurag @Mohan Mishra @Akshita @Sparsha

The idea is to reach 100% refund ticket automation, we might start with lower number as of now and gradually keep covering the edge cases via the script.

We will also measure the % of tickets automated on a daily level once the code is pushed to production.
cc: @Pankhudi Jain @Amit Shukla @Venkatesan @Mohan @Anjali

We are thinking how can we solve 255Mn errors which happens in our system in a day? Should we worry about all these errors or what are the errors we should worry about? How can we get to know about this quickly?

• Which are the top priority errors for us? - Based on impact (across merchants, across PGs, across flows, etc) / count / anything else?
• How many of these errors are because of Juspay vs External?
• Can we try to do auto-debugging here by giving an understanding of our code to AI?
• How can we fix these things faster and keep our systems clean?
These are also coming as part of our Observability product. Monitoring the errors and fixing the high priority ones.

messagesWithoutThreadId.text:
*[UPDATE ON UNMAPPED ERRORS]*

We were working on a script that analyses the error codes and error messages from the gateway and categorises them as TERMINAL(Stops PT sync) and INTERMEDIATE_TERMINAL(Reduces PT Sync to 3 counts) state.

Post analysing & categorising the data further use case was to unify these error messages to JUSPAY ERROR MESSAGES. We were able to upgrade the already built fine tune model with around 4k more mapped error messages to enhance the accuracy to ~>90% so that it can be used by the script to get these JEM mapped and inserted directly into the GSM table.

We ran this script on last Friday i.e 31st May and mapped more than `2500` UNMAPPED ERROR MESSAGES. Attaching data from 1st JUNE till today <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/11WK20XGJFOgCp-gtLLhrFzHaf7ki2oNVFjqIU8DoQOA/edit#gid=366687764|here>. We have only around 157 mappable messages.

*Calling out the limitations:*
1. We had a check on the count of the error message. SO if the count of err msg is less than 100 we ignored it to avoid incorrect terminal statuses. 
2. Dynamic messages were not mapped.
3. NULL err code or msg were not mapped.
4. Any new message coming from the gateways will be mapped in next round of script.
*Next steps:*
1. Add REFUND use cases.
2. Figure out a way to handle dynamic messages. 
3. Figure out mappings where we are getting NULL.
4. Have a CRON to sweep new messages periodically. 
cc: @Divyanshu Varshney @Akhil Nair @Prashant Khandelwal @Taral Shah @Pankhudi Jain @malav @Venkatesan

*@here* Prod deployment announcement:mega:!! We have deployed the following features in prod:
• Improved workflow execution time
    ◦ Workflow execution API call time out set at 30 sec
    ◦ Individual workflow step execution time out set at 120 sec. This has been done to prevent jamming of resources, to prevent infinite loops etc.
    ◦ API polling from front end to get the workflow output
    ◦ With this, we can support really long workflows, by breaking the workflows into smaller steps(For n steps, the time allotted will be n * 120sec). 
    ◦ Once the workflow is executed(or timed out), you will get the response in the UI. The `outputObj` key will have the email draft response.
With help of the above, we have been able to execute workflows for 60+ tickets out of the 75 that we have tried. 7 have issues, which we are in the process of fixing. The rest have input data issue. @Yashi is validating the accuracy of the outputs of the workflows.

Note: The present refunds workflow is a single step workflow(till now). Hence, it will time out at 120sec, at present.

messagesWithoutThreadId.text:
*Sharing the flow we ideated for killing dashboard ticket category - "gateway deletion". "Gateway deletion" contributes to second largest count in the dashboard category of tickets after "login issues".* 

*Problem:* Currently, merchants write us an email for all kinds of gateway deletion requests and one of our team member performs necessary checks for that merchant <> pg combination and then raises it to @Anjali for gateway deletion.

For the same, we are proposing a solution to enable the "Delete Gateway" button for admin and users having similar ACLs. Right now it is not enabled for merchants.

*Flow:*
• User clicks on the `Delete Gateway` button 
• The api checks for any `successful txns in the last 6 months` , `any active mandates` or `refunds in process`
• If any of the above checks is `false`, take 2nd level of confirmation and allow to `delete gateway` 
• If any of the above is `true`, show the report to user, take 2nd level of confirmation and `disable gateway` (if not disabled already) and 
    ◦ If `successful txns in the last 6 months`  = true, allow deletion after 6 months from the last txn 
    ◦ If `any active mandates` = true, do not allow deletion 
    ◦ If `refunds in process`  = true, allow deletion after 30 days from the refund created date 
@Anjali @Venkatesan @Ankit Jain @Sarvani Kara @Mohan Mishra @Darshan Sithan

messagesWithoutThreadId.text:
*@here* Prod deployment announcement:mega:!! We have deployed multi-step support for workflows in prod :drum_with_drumsticks::drum_with_drumsticks:

*Single step -> multi step refunds workflow*
• The present single step refunds workflow logic has been split into multiple steps
• The execution of the multi step workflow has been tested on all the refunds tickets mentioned in <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1J2ZU8kT-95-iokehHMoA0Z-UQJLrgfV5u49XIBJyeSs/edit?usp=sharing|this sheet>
• The new workflow has passed for all tickets which were resolved by the single step workflow
• The multi step workflow has passed for most of the tickets which were resulting to timeouts in the single step workflow(a demo video attached)
• We have split the existing workflow to avoid many API calls from a single step(like API calls in loops). We have achieved this by bringing the loops out of a single script to the workflow step level(demo video attached and explained below)
*Advantages of the multi-step workflow:*
• Using the framework, building workflows is similar to creating flowcharts. Hence, deep technical knowledge is not needed. Simply draw the logic in a flowchart, then replicate it in the workflow. Additionally, you can click on a step in the flow chart and add your code!
• 1 step has an execution time limit of 120 sec. Simply break a complex step into n multiple steps to get (120 * n) sec time limit. Eg. API calls inside loops
• Visual separation of steps and logical path taken to resolve a ticket
• Smaller scripts make debugging easier
• Execution errors can easily point out at which step the execution has failed
• Builder of a workflow can determine if steps need to be split into multiple or kept together. Both the number of steps and conditions will be determined by the workflow builder.
*Concepts:*
• Workflow step - Represents actionables in a workflow.
    ◦ This can contain a script. Script needs to have an `execute(inputData)` 
    ◦ Workflow steps point to `route conditions` which in turn point to other workflow steps
    ◦ A script in a workflow step needs to return `outputData` . This can be a dictionary in which all info can be stored that will be used in later steps in the workflow.
    ◦ This `outputData` becomes the input for the next workflow step/route condition. In this way, values are propagated across the workflow
• Route condition - Represents conditional branching in a workflow. 
    ◦ A route condition can contain a script which returns a boolean. 
    ◦ Route conditions have groups and priorities
    ◦ Depending on the priority, all route conditions are executed.
    ◦ If a route condition returns `true` then the next workflow step, pointed by the route condition will be executed and so on.
• Support for loops across steps is built, same as what we do in case of flow charts

*Demo videos(ticket No-* 570971)*:*
• The ticket has 8 order ids
• In the first video, we execute the ticket using the single step workflow, which gives timeout as a lot of API calls are happening to resolve the 8 order ids
• In the second video, we execute the ticket with the multi-step workflow, which splits the execution into multiple steps. The APi calls are split into steps and hence, do not time out and provide the required result.
• Videos have been attached demonstrating the template refunds multi-step workflow and the prototype application to create workflows(in future) as well.

*Ease of building workflows in future:*
• Have worked with <@U05H7CN2XE1> to create a prototype that uses image recognition to create JSON. A demo video of this has been attached.
• A future workflow building journey can be: "draw a workflow" -> click a picture of the same -> Upload to the application -> Entire template workflow skeleton will be generated -> click on individual steps to add your scripts
• Advance mode like UI(similar to advance mode in SSA) can be provided to alter structures of template workflows, if needed
Thanks @satoru @Yash Daga @xenacro for helping with building this.

Lets add txn and other workflows to automate as many tickets as possible :salute:

*Note*:
1. Due to present constraints, a workflow step has to point to a route condition(except the terminating steps). We will add support for workflow step -> workflow step connection in future.
2. Will make this as default for refunds today
cc: @Venkatesan @Mohan Mishra @Yashi @Mohan @Pankhudi Jain

messagesWithoutThreadId.text:
*@here* Prod deployment announcement:mega:!! We have deployed the following features to prod:

• Auto trigger email support in workflows(automatically workflow is triggered when merchant raises a ticket -> workflow executes -> email with desired response can be sent to the merchant from workflow level itself)
• Integration with MID list API(rectification of MID
Additionally, :drum_with_drumsticks::drum_with_drumsticks: we have launched code and PR based template workflow builder support using which the workflow builders can configure their template workflows by writing code and raising PRs.

*The workflow building journey journey(demo videos attached:*
• Workflow builder pulls code from the repo
• Makes logical changes to one/many step(s)
• Adds/removes steps
• Raises a PR with these changes
• PR is reviewed by owners of the workflow -> approved and merged
• A Jenkins build is triggered and the changes are deployed to production(to the default workflow)
• Here on all relevant tickets will be resolved using the updated logic
*Framework rules of building a workflow:*
• Under the `templates` directory, sub-directories are created to represent different template workflows
• To define a  template workflow, the workflow builders need to define the following structure:
    ◦ A directory of each template workflow
    ◦ Logic of each step to be written in individual files in the directory
    ◦ there will have to be a `meta.yaml` file defined for all template workflows. This should contain:
        ▪︎ `templateWorkflowId` - The uuid with which the builder would create/update their template workflow
        ▪︎ `rootStepFileName` - Name of the file of the root step of the template workflow from where execution will start
        ▪︎ `templateWorkflowName` - Name of the template workflow
• In every Step file, there has to be an `execute(inputData)` function defined where inputData is a json. It is this function that gets executed bu the framework when the step is executed.
• To redirect to the next step from the present step, simply store the file name of the next step to be executed in `outputData["next_step_name"]`
• In this way the workflow builder *can create any number of steps* they want
• After all the changes and local testing, workflow builders need to raise a PR to `diagnostics-release` branch.
• After the PR is merged, the templated workflow will be uploaded by API calls via the jenkins pipeline.

*The demo(videos and PR link attached):*
In the attached demo videos, we have:
• Executed a workflow on a ticket Number 565309
• The output of this does not have any key called `testMessage`
• Then, inside the `analyse refund logs` step, we have added some logic(added a key `testMessage` )
• This change has been pushed to a branch and a PR has been raised to `diagnostics-release` branch
• The PR is merged and the workflow is executed again for the same ticket
• This time, the output of the workflow has a key `testMessage` and the `analyse refund logs` step has the added line of code as well.
A huge shoutout:mega::mega: to @Yash Daga and @xenacro for helping with launching this within 1 day(well, almost!)

*Note*:
• The workflow is not being updated via jenkins yet, hence when a PR is merged, workflow builders would need to reach out to the dev team, to upload the changes in prod(we will run a script until we are able to run it via jenkins). 
• Also, we are not yet rendering the UI for these type of template workflows, which are defined via PRs. Will add this support if needed later
• If any workflow builders feel that rendering route conditions will be beneficial for understanding their template workflows  better, then they can mark their route conditions between #rc_start_number and #rc_end_number. This is optional. We might pick these details later if we need to show these in the UI
• Please take a look at the refunds workflow in `templates/refunds/refunds-status` in `diagnostics-release` branch in turing where examples of all the rules are available(start with the meta file there)

PR link: <https://bitbucket.juspay.net/projects/PICAF/repos/turing/pull-requests/798/overview>

messagesWithoutThreadId.text:
@channel

To achieve our goal of `0 Technical Errors` this quarter, we began by addressing decode errors in our system, as they were contributing the most to the issue.

Applying the *80-20 rule*, we first focused on incoming webhooks and sync processes, where the error counts were highest.

We are thrilled to announce that we have successfully reduced decode errors from *80k per day to just 19k per day*, with the majority of improvements coming from fixing webhook and sync implementations for gateways like Paytm_v2 and Easebuzz.

In addition to manual fixes, we leveraged Haskell tools to address incorrect sync flow implementations and will continue using these tools to maintain this momentum.

Looking ahead, we’ll also be introducing plugins that will help us further restrict the use of incorrect code practice due to which these decode errors are occurring, bringing us even closer to our goal.

A big shoutout to @sandeep reddy @Yashasvi Rana and @imdad for their relentless efforts, and to @Chaitanya for her support in implementing these plugins.

messagesWithoutThreadId.text:
*@Amit Shukla* 
*Issue brief: Merchants are unable to initiate refunds/refunds are getting failed for split payments where one of the payment methods is TWID. This is happening because TWID is passing incorrect refund amount values to Juspay.*
We have identified a major issue in the split payment refunds flow between TWID and Juspay. Currently, during the split refunds process, Juspay performs a `/refundInquiry` call to TWID before initiating refunds. TWID is returning incorrect values for `pg_refund_request` and `points_refund_request`, which Juspay then uses to process the refunds with either the parent gateway or TWID.
To clarify the problem further, here is an example:
• *Order ID:* o-54246219-r616kn
• *MID:* manmatters
• Order amount: 2114.10, (Split: T1, PayU: 2070.10 and T2, TWID: 44.0)
*TWID's Current (Erroneous) Calculation:*
Refundable amount via the parent gateway = Order Amount - Already refunded amount
2114.10 - 699.25 = 1414.85
*Expected (Accurate) Calculation:*
Refundable amount via the parent gateway = (Order Amount - TWID txn amount) - Already refunded amount
(2114.10 - 44.0) - 699.25 = 1370.75
I have raised this issue with TWID and we are working with them to get this fixed.
That said, during our discussions and debugging, @Krishna and I realized that Juspay now has the capability to perform these calculations internally, which wasn’t the case when this implementation was originally done. Given this, can we eliminate dependency on TWID for this calculation and migrate it entirely to Juspay.
@Rahul Agarwal - FYI
cc: @Akshita @Amrutheshwar O @Viz @Venkatesan

messagesWithoutThreadId.text:
This is an idea for writing workflow logic via AI with less chance of errors:

First, We will need to give "context" to AI on what does the refund workflow do and the txn workflow do(something like AI consumes the workflow and explains it like a podcast).

Then,
For all unhandled cases(where automated emails are not sent):
• We will create a "context" by storing `ticket details JSON` and `a solution algorithm in english sentences`(like how we explain people).
• We will make the first few entries manually.
• Then, whenever a new ticket comes(where we have not replied automatically), the system will try generating an english sentence-based algorithm.
• We will get an alert and at the end of the day call, can get the english algorithm reviewed or edited by people.
• These english algorithms will be prompts. Very easy to review and edit.
• Once this is done, we can try generating workflow code based on this via AI(we are already experimenting on it).
• We will keep these workflow generated code separately and only merge with live code post review.
• This might save much time and will gradually help us to cover more cases automatically.
• Vision: an unhandled ticket comes -> AI creates an algorithm -> AI generates code -> Human review of algorithm and code -> Merge to live workflow.
Feels like a positive experiment to do. Thoughts?
cc: @Venkatesan @satoru @xenacro @Yash Daga

messagesWithoutThreadId.text:
@here To improve the stability and predictability of our MGA-related features, we are *removing a legacy fallback mechanism* that previously handled cases where `supported_payment_flows` configuration was missing.

Going forward, if the `supported_payment_flows` configuration is absent for an MGA, the system will *strictly adhere to defined behavior* (e.g., the feature will be disabled or default to no flows) instead of relying on an outdated fallback.
This change is being rolled out incrementally to specific `mgaIds`. Please refer to [<https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1L4neWdYzikNG25XF7Fl4V9Vyatx4F5DHlCAa9kAnplM/edit?gid=0#gid=0|data>] for the list of affected and eligible MGA IDs.
We will be closely monitoring this transition. Should you observe any unexpected behavior or glitches, please report them immediately.

Config name : `disable_account_details_level_pf_fallback` 
Tracker link : <https://euler-x.internal.svc.k8s.mum.juspay.net/db-configs/service-configs/disable_account_details_level_pf_fallback>

cc: @Richa @Shobhit @Azhar

messagesWithoutThreadId.text:
<!subteam^S02J9M8HKPZ> Sent the below notification to merchants who have enabled cybersource.

This is to inform you about a *mandatory security update from Cybersource*. Effective *1st October 2025*, Cybersource will *deprecate secret key & key ID-based authentication* for SOAP API connections and transition to *P12 certificate-based authentication*.
To help you comply with these new requirements, we are updating our platform to allow configuration of P12 certificates for your Cybersource account via the Juspay Dashboard.

*Action Items for You*

*Step 1: Update Current Authentication (ETA: 15th September 2025)*
Update your existing keys by following these steps:
1. Log in to the Cybersource Business Center:<https://businesscentertest.cybersource.com/| ><https://businesscentertest.cybersource.com>
2. In the left navigation panel, go to:
3.  *Payment Configuration > Key Management*
4. Click “*+ Generate Key”*
5. Select “*SOAP Toolkit”* and click “*Generate Key”*
Refer to the official guide here:<https://developer.cybersource.com/docs/cybs/en-us/security-keys/user/all/ada/security-keys/keys-manage/keys-soap-intro.html| Cybersource SOAP Key Management>
*Note*: While your current set of keys will continue to function until they expire, *you will not be able to generate new keys after 15th September 2025*.
1. Log in to your *Juspay Dashboard*
2.  Navigate to: *Payments > PG Control Centre > Gateways > Cybersource Account* and update the newly generated key.
*Step 2: Generate P12 Certificate* 
Follow Cybersource’s official guide to generate your P12 certificate: <https://developer.cybersource.com/docs/cybs/en-us/so-p12/migration/all/so/so-p12/so-p12-intro.html|Generate P12 Certificate – Cybersource Guide>

*Step 3: Prepare for Certificate Upload (ETA for this step: 30th September 2025)*
Keep your P12 certificate file and password ready as per Step 2. We will notify you once the Juspay Dashboard is ready to accept P12 certificate uploads.

We appreciate your cooperation in implementing this critical security upgrade. If you have any questions, please reach out to our support team or your Cybersource point of contact.

cc: @Amit Shukla @sohini @Divya Arora
messagesWithoutThreadId.name: G Sai Vana Shree
